learning_to_win.probleme: Players have shots but don’t know how to combine them to win
learning_to_win.diagnostic: Players with solid strokes fail to link serves, receives, and follow-ups into point-winning combinations.
causes_communes: Serving patterns that don’t set up best attacks (e.g., serving topspin while relying on looping backspin)
Overhitting early in rallies instead of constructing the point
Avoiding weaker opponents and thus not forcing one’s own patterns
Only reacting against stronger opponents and never practicing own combinations

debutant: Identify which rallies you are best at and choose serves/receives that lead into those rallies.
Play both weaker and stronger players; against weaker players, practice imposing simple combinations.
intermediaire: Strengthen strengths: develop shots that get you into your preferred rally type and shots that make you even stronger in it.
Strengthen weaknesses: add shots that help you survive weak rally types and shots that keep you out of them.
avance: Pair serves with the returns you want (e.g., short backspin to invite a push and open a loop vs. backspin).
Practice match play that prioritizes using planned combinations over ad-hoc winners; learn to pick shots.
Regularly schedule sets vs. slightly weaker players (~100 rating points lower) to rehearse patterns under control.

exercices_complementaires.description: Choose a serve (e.g., short backspin) that tends to elicit a predictable return (long push); execute the planned third-ball attack that fits your strengths; repeat.

erreurs_a_eviter: Serving patterns that contradict your best follow-up
Going for winners on the first ball instead of building the point
Playing only stronger opponents and never rehearsing your own combinations

terminologie_extrait.definition: Sequence where partner hits two balls to your backhand and one to your forehand; you play BH, then step-around FH from BH corner, then FH from wide FH, and repeat.
One player always hits down the line while the other always hits crosscourt, producing a figure-eight ball path; then switch roles.

six_step_training_progression.probleme: Players stall on basic strokes and fail to progress to complex, game-like training
six_step_training_progression.diagnostic: Overemphasis on simple rallying prevents integration of footwork, decision-making, and whole-table patterns.
causes_communes: Waiting to ‘perfect’ basics before learning advanced drills
Skipping serve/receive starts that simulate real points
Neglecting randomness and choice in drills

debutant: Step One – Stroke & Stroke: FH–FH crosscourt, BH–BH crosscourt, FH to BH down-the-line; once you can hit ~20 in a row, progress.
Limit pure stroke warm-up to short blocks (2–10 minutes total per session) as shots become automatic.
intermediaire: Step Two – Move & Stroke: one-one FH footwork from FH and from BH corner; one-one BH footwork.
Step Three – Different Strokes: alternate BH↔FH; Two-One (Falkenberg); Cross-Court/Down-the-Line.
Step Four – Choose & Stroke: random side-to-side with a binary choice between FH or BH to meet the ball; prioritize correct first move.
avance: Step Five – Choose & Move: random FH-only, random BH-only, BH then random FH pattern; random deep-serve attack (choose wing by style); Alternate Two-One where third ball may go BH or wide FH.
Step Six – Whole Table: full-table random placement; serve backspin, receive push anywhere, attack (mostly loop) from appropriate wing.
Start many drills with serve/receive sequences (e.g., deep backspin serve → loop; short serve → flip) to mirror matches.

exercices_complementaires.description: Prepend drills with realistic starts: partner serves short or deep; you respond (flip, push, loop) and then continue the planned pattern.

metriques_progression: Reach ~20 consecutive hits per basic stroke before advancing.
Reduce basic warm-up to 2–5 minutes per stroke once consistent.
erreurs_a_eviter: Spending entire sessions for years on FH–FH and BH–BH only
Starting drills without realistic serve/receive when ready
Over-anticipating in random drills and moving the wrong first step

meta.article_title: Play Both Weaker and Stronger Players

play_both_weaker_and_stronger_players.probleme: Overplaying stronger opponents and underusing weaker ones in practice
play_both_weaker_and_stronger_players.diagnostic: Against only stronger players, you mostly react and cannot test new shots or combinations; development stalls.
causes_communes: Belief that only stronger opposition leads to improvement
Stopping experiments early because points are lost versus stronger players

debutant: Use weaker players to rehearse new techniques under control; treat results as practice, not outcome-focused.
intermediaire: Once a technique works vs. weaker players, deploy it against peers; then bring it to matches vs. stronger players.
Example sequence: serve backspin to invite push, then loop vs. backspin; start with weaker opponents to build this pattern.
avance: Cycle opponents intentionally: weaker for development, peers for integration, stronger for stress-testing strengths.

exercices_complementaires.description: Serve backspin; expect long push; execute opening loop; continue point focusing on follow-up selection; begin versus weaker players.

erreurs_a_eviter: Judging a new technique’s viability solely on results vs. stronger players
Abandoning development due to short-term losses in practice

meta.article_title: The 7 Habits of Highly Effective Table Tennis Players

the_7_habits_of_highly_effective_table_t.diagnostic: Players don’t consistently apply behaviors that drive improvement and competitive readiness.
causes_communes: Low practice enthusiasm
Passive approach to improvement
Absence of specific short-, intermediate-, and long-term goals

debutant: Cultivate enjoyment of practice and competition; never give up in sessions or matches.
intermediaire: Be proactive about finding ways to improve; think analytically about your game and tactics; pursue high standards.
Set concrete goals across time horizons.
avance: Synergize habits: rigorous standards plus tactical reflection, sustained competitiveness, and goal-tracking to optimize gains.

erreurs_a_eviter: Underestimating opponents rather than respecting while seeking to dominate

terminologie_extrait.definition: A period focused only on correcting technique by drilling with a coach or practice partner while avoiding matches that reinforce old habits.
terminologie_extrait.contexte: Recommendation to drop tournaments/matches and isolate the new technique.

terminologie_extrait.definition: Practicing the proper technique without the ball to ingrain the motion.
terminologie_extrait.contexte: Advice to rehearse the new technique repeatedly until it is automatic.

changing_bad_technique.diagnostic: Players use halfway measures, revert during competition, or fail to address root causes like grip and stance.
causes_communes: Returning to matches before the new technique is ingrained
Minor tweaks when major changes are needed
Incorrect grip or stance causing recurring faults
Lack of clear understanding of what to change

debutant: Temporarily stop tournaments and match play; drill only with a coach or practice partner to isolate changes.
Exaggerate the correct movement to overcome old patterns; rehearse via shadow practice repeatedly.
intermediaire: Study top players performing the stroke; visualize yourself doing it, then shadow it while visualizing.
Audit and correct grip and stance before addressing downstream symptoms.
avance: Plan a competition return timeline (e.g., months ahead) and train specifically toward it; consider a 2-month match-free block for major changes.
Work closely with a coach to diagnose and supervise changes.

exercices_complementaires.description: Record target stroke; compare to model execution; note deficits (e.g., shoulder rotation, weight shift); repeat after exaggerated-cue practice.
exercices_complementaires.materiel: camera or phone; table or open space

exercices_complementaires.description: Perform slow exaggerated versions of the corrected motion, then high-rep shadow sets until movement feels natural.

metriques_progression: Set a competition re-entry target date after an extended correction block.
erreurs_a_eviter: Re-ingraining bad habits by competing too soon
Switching from one flawed technique to another without expert guidance

terminologie_extrait.definition: Practicing strokes and footwork without a ball, tailored to your style, as part of a daily fitness routine.
terminologie_extrait.contexte: Daily recommendation to perform set counts of shadow strokes and movements.

march_21_2011_shadow_practice_your_shots.probleme: Players neglect off-table shadow practice that builds mechanics and fitness
causes_communes: Underestimating benefits of daily no-ball repetitions
Shadow routines not tailored to playing style

debutant: Spend 5–10 minutes daily on shadow strokes and footwork; include 50–100 forehands, backhands, forehand loops, backhand loops, and side-to-side patterns.
intermediaire: Adjust counts to your style (e.g., extra FH loops for loopers; chopping for choppers); add sequences like stepping in to flip short, then loop vs. backspin and follow with topspin.
Occasionally play out imaginary points while shadowing to add realism.
avance: Chain movements into style-specific combinations (e.g., loop vs. backspin → smash/loop vs. topspin) within the shadow set.

metriques_progression: 50–100 reps per listed stroke per day.
erreurs_a_eviter: Skipping daily practice because no table is available
Ignoring receive/transition moves in the routine

meta.article_title: Shadow Practice For Strokes and Footwork

terminologie_extrait.definition: Practicing shots without the ball to improve sharpness and steadiness.
terminologie_extrait.contexte: Applied to drives, loops, and side-to-side footwork across levels.

shadow_practice_for_strokes_and_footwork.probleme: How to structure effective shadow practice by level
causes_communes: Practicing back-and-forth without returning to ready position
Repeating non-game movements rather than match-realistic patterns

debutant: Work with a coach to confirm correct form; perform 100 FH and 100 BH drives, 100 FH and 100 BH loops, and 100 side-to-side steps while stroking.
Execute all three stroke phases: backswing, forward swing, then return to ready position (triangular motion).
intermediaire: Increase speed, crispness, and power; mimic common match movements (e.g., alternating powerful FH loops from wide BH and wide FH).
avance: Add randomness: imagine a specific opponent and play out rallies at the level you aim to reach; include receive patterns (step in to drop short, step out and attack the next ball).

metriques_progression: 100 repetitions per listed beginner shadow element.
erreurs_a_eviter: Going directly from forward swing to backswing without resetting
Failing to visualize realistic sequences during advanced shadowing

june_6_2011_practice_matches.probleme: Players treat practice matches like tournaments and miss development opportunities
june_6_2011_practice_matches.diagnostic: In practice, winning becomes the only priority; players avoid using developing shots, skip situational goals, and fail to train end-game tactics.
causes_communes: No clear intent for practice matches
Same approach to weaker, peer, and stronger opponents

debutant: Treat practice matches as chances to use the shots you want in the future; give 100% effort while prioritizing development.
intermediaire: Versus weaker players: target weaknesses or pit your weaknesses against their strengths to learn.
Versus peers: balance improvement and winning based on upcoming events; practice your normal game with selected additions.
avance: Versus stronger players: stress-test your strengths at higher pace.
In close ends of games during practice, play to win using best tactics to train decision-making under pressure.

erreurs_a_eviter: Coasting or withholding effort in practice matches
Refusing to use developing skills due to short-term score pressure
Applying identical goals regardless of opponent strength
